content:
Diagnosis
	1. Hurthle cell thyroid carcinoma T4aN1M1
	Date of diagnosis
	January 2024

	Treatment aim
	Palliative

	Summary of completed treatment and relevant dates

	Surgery
	15 Jan 2024 Total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection

	Radiotherapy
	1 Mar 2024 - 15 Mar 2024 Palliative radiotherapy to T7 vertebral metastasis

	Systemic therapy
	1. Lenvatinib 24mg daily commenced 1 Feb 2024
	2. Dose reduction to 14mg daily on 1 Mar 2024 due to grade 3 hypertension
	3. Further dose reduction to 10mg daily on 15 Apr 2024 due to persistent fatigue

	Clinical studies
	Not eligible

	Current disease status
	Progressive disease with new liver metastases

	Current issues
	1. Worsening bone pain
	2. Grade 2 fatigue
	3. Controlled hypertension on treatment

	Summary of consultation

I reviewed [redacted name] today who attended with her husband. Unfortunately, recent imaging shows disease progression with new liver metastases despite Lenvatinib therapy. The CT scan from 20 Apr 2024 demonstrates three new liver lesions measuring up to 2.8cm, while the known bone metastases show mixed response with some lesions stable and others showing progression. Thyroglobulin has increased from 2500 to 4200 over the past month.

She reports worsening bone pain, particularly in her thoracic spine and right hip, requiring increased analgesia. Her blood pressure is now well-controlled on amlodipine 10mg daily, but she continues to experience significant fatigue limiting her daily activities. Performance status has declined to ECOG 2.

On examination, there is tenderness over T7 vertebra and right hip. Liver span is increased to 16cm with a palpable edge but no tenderness. No focal neurological deficits identified.

	Further investigations
	1. MRI spine to assess for cord compression
	2. Bone scan to reassess extent of skeletal disease

	Medication prescribed
	1. Increased MST to 60mg BD from 30mg BD
	2. Added Pregabalin 75mg BD for neuropathic pain

	Follow up
	Urgent review in 2 weeks with scan results

	Required GP actions
	1. Weekly blood pressure monitoring
	2. Monitor renal function
	3. Titrate analgesia as needed following pain team review
